grounding: This narrative review summarizes the literature on factors related to eye care access and utilization in the United States. Using the Healthy People 2030 framework, this review investigates social determinants of health associated with general and follow-up engagement, screenings, diagnostic visits, treatment, technology, and teleophthalmology. We provide hypotheses for these documented eye care disparities, featuring qualitative, patient-centered research. Lastly, we provide recommendations in the hopes of appropriately eliminating these disparities and reimagining eye care.
generated_text: This narrative review examines disparities in eye care access and utilization across diverse populations. It explores factors contributing to inequities in ophthalmological services, including socioeconomic status, race/ethnicity, geographic location, and health literacy. The review synthesizes current literature on barriers to eye care, highlighting the impact on vision health outcomes and quality of life. Findings emphasize the need for targeted interventions and policy changes to promote health equity in eye care delivery and improve overall population eye health.
